header_1: H5N1 in Wild Birds in Russian Federation
content_1: . A total of 367 wild birds were found dead on June 5 on Ubsu-Nur Lake, Republic of Tuva, near the border of Mongolia. Affected species included great crested grebe (Podiceps cristatus), goosander (Mergus merganser), grey heron (Ardea cinerea), gadwall (Anas strepera) and Eurasian spoonbill (Platalea leucorodia). Samples tested positive for H5N1 by PCR.
content_2: . There were a total of eight cases of H5N1 bird flu in five governorates during June: 1 in Dakahlia, 2 in Fayoum, 1 in Menoufia, 1 in Qalioubiya, and 3 in Sixth of October. Most of the outbreaks were in household poultry; one occurred on a commercial farm in Dakahlia governorate.
content_3: . On June 19 an outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in Narayanganj District was reported.
content_4: . The Participatory Disease Surveillance & Response (PDSR) programme covers 71,033 villages in 84% of Indonesia’s 448 districts and municipalities in 29 of its 33 provinces, using a network of 33 Local Disease Control Centres. During May 2010, PDSR conducted surveillance in 1,978 villages (2.8%). The overall H5N1 bird flu incidence was 0.6 infected villages per 1,000 villages under surveillance. The four provinces with the highest incidence values were Yogyakarta, Sumatera Barat, Kalimantan Timur, and Lampung. Some newly infected villages were found during May with 14 in Sumatra, 29 in Java, and 2 in Kalimantan.
content_5: . Quang Nam and Thai Nguyen provinces experienced outbreaks of H5N1 bird flu in June. The most recent outbreak was on July 18 in chickens and Muscovy ducks in Gia Lai province.
content_6:
. An outbreak of H5N1 bird flu that killed hundreds of chickens in Bengkulu province may have spread to humans. A 19-year-old was admitted to M Yunus regional hospital with suspected bird flu on August 6. The patient had developed a fever and sore throat after burying chickens days before. “We’re treating a bird flu suspect patient in an isolation unit, but we’re still not sure whether the patient has bird flu or not,” director of M Yunus hospital, Dr. Zulman Zuri confirmed. “For now we don’t suspect bird flu infection because patient is getting better after being treated here. We’re collecting throat swab every day for three days and send it to NHIRD, Ministry of Health laboratory. We have done chest x-ray too, but still waiting for the laboratory result,” added Zulman. The hospital has prepared two special rooms for bird flu patients that are guarded and equipped for the safety of patients and health workers.
